title-group.article-title: Determination of the genotoxic effects of Convolvulus arvensis extracts on corn (Zea mays L.) seeds

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biology, Atatürk University, Erzurum, Turkey
2Department of Biology, Erzincan University, Erzincan, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Guleray Agar, Department of Biology, Atatürk University, Erzurum 25240, Turkey. Email: gagar@atauni.edu.tr

abstract.p: In this research, the methanolic extracts of Convolvulus arvensis were tested for genotoxic and inhibitor activity on the total soluble protein content and the genomic template stability against corn Zea mays L. seed. The methanol extracts of leaf, stem and root of C. arvensis were diluted to 50, 75 and 100 μl concentrations and applied to corn seed. The total soluble protein and genomic template stability results were compared with the control. The results showed that especially 100 μl extracts of diluted leaf, stem and root had a strong inhibitory activity on the genomic template stability. The changes occurred in random amplification of polymorphic DNA (RAPD) profiles of C. arvensis extract treatment included variation in band intensity, loss of bands and appearance of new bands compared with control. Also, the results obtained from this study revealed that the increase in the concentrations of C. arvensis extract increased the total soluble protein content in maize. The results suggested that RAPD analysis and total protein analysis could be applied as a suitable biomarker assay for the detection of genotoxic effects of plant allelochemicals.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Convolvulus arvensis L. (Tubiflorae: Convolvulaceae), commonly known as field bindweed or small-flowered morning glory, is a perennial herbaceous broadleaf weed, which spreads primarily by means of lateral roots and root buds. C. arvensis is particularly problematic in cereals, corn (Zea mays L.) and root crops but can also pose problems in horticultural crops, vineyards, ornamental plantings and waste areas (Holm et al., 1977).

It is widespread in cultivated fields in Turkey and invades field crops as well as garden and pastures. This species has little economic value toxic to organism and invasion. Invasive species have the potential to affect the structure of native plant communities (Mack et al., 2000; Vitousek, 1990; Woitke and Dietz, 2002). Invasive species may displace natives through competition, changes in ecosystem processes or allelopathy, among other mechanisms (Hierro and Callaway, 2003; Levine et al., 2003; Mallik and Prescott, 2001), and the relative importance of these factors remains unclear.

The allelopathy potential achieved by many invasive plants may result from ecological advantages afforded by plant traits that are novel to the recipient community. Allelopathic chemicals can also persist in soil, affecting both neighboring plants and those planted in succession (Chon and Kim, 2002; Khanh et al., 2006; Rizvi and Rizvi, 1992). Commonly cited effects of allelopathy include reduced seed germination (Ahn and Chung, 2000; Turker et al., 2008) and seedling growth. There is no common mode of action or physiological target site for all allelochemicals (Kato-Noguchi et al., 2002) even though some plant extracts are known to have allelopathic effects on cell division, pollen germination (Gill and Sandhu, 1994; Turker et al., 2008), nutrient uptake, photosynthesis, specific enzyme function (Celik and Aslantürk, 2006; Kocacaliskan and Terzi, 2001), genomic template stability (GTS) and total soluble protein content of the seedlings gradually decreased.

Recently, several studies have demonstrated that extracts of C. arvensis reduced seed germination in plants (Sodaeizadeh et al., 2009; Soufan and Almouemar, 2009). Whether extracts of C. arvensis have genotoxic effects on corn (Zea mays L.) seeds has not been reported up to the present. This study investigated whether methanol extracts of C. arvensis have any genotoxic effect and inhibitor activity on the total soluble protein content and GTS against corn Zea mays L. seed.

sec.title: Plant material
sec.p: The weed plant used in the present study was collected in August 2009 from different locations of Erzurum vicinity, Turkey. The plants were collected at flowering stage, dried in shadow, the leaves and roots were separated from the stem, and all parts of the plant were ground in a grinder to achieve a size of 2 mm in diameter.

sec.title: Preparation of the methanol extracts (MeOH)
sec.p: Methanol is a common solvent used for allelochemical analyses because this combination exhibits a good ability to extract both polar and nonpolar compounds, therefore most potential phytotoxins of the plant can be extracted (Fujii et al., 2003). The dried and powdered leaves, stems and roots (500 g) were extracted with 1 L of methanol using a Soxhlet extractor for 72 h at a temperature not exceeding the boiling point of the solvent. The extracts were filtered using filter paper (Whatman No.1) and then concentrated in vacuo at 40°C using a rotary evaporator. The residues obtained were stored in a freezer at −80°C until further tests.

sec.title: Treatments of extracts on corn seeds
sec.p: Corn seeds, selected by uniform size, were surface sterilized with 2.5% (w/v) NaOCl for 3 min, washed with sterile distilled water and paper blotted. The seeds were soaked in sterile distilled water for 1 h and then 15 seeds were germinated in 15 cm dia petri dishes on 4 layers of sterile Whatman No. 1 filter paper. The plant extracts were diluted with deionized water to prepare the concentrations of 50, 75 and 100 μl. 20 ml extract was added per petri dish as per treatment. The seeds in petri dishes were allowed to germinate at 25°C in the dark. After 7 days of incubation, total soluble protein level was measured in the maize seedlings (Bradford, 1976). The data are expressed as mean ± SD. Significant differences (p ≤ 0.05) between the control and each treatment group were analyzed by performing one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) using Duncan test. Inhibitory rate (%) was calculated using the equation: (1 − x/y) × 100, where y and x are the average values detected in the control and each sample treated, respectively. Furthermore, treated plants were utilized for DNA extraction. The random amplification of polymorphic DNA (RAPD) assays were performed 8 days after incubation (Figure 1).

caption.p: Random amplification of polymorphic DNA (RAPD) profiles of genomic DNA obtained from primer OPA13 in corn seed exposed to different Convolvulus arvensis extracts (C: control, G: stem, Y: leaf, K: root. 1: 50 μl, 2: 75 μl and 3: 100 μl).
Comparison of total soluble protein level in maize seedlings exposed to different Convolvulus arvensis extracts (C: control, G: stem Y: leaf, K: root. 1: 50 μl, 2: 75 μl and 3: 100 μl).

sec.title: DNA extraction
sec.p: Genomic DNA was extracted from powdered plant materials using a modified method described by Lin and Quiros (2001). Approximately 10–15 mg tissue samples from each plant species were snap frozen in liquid nitrogen in 2 ml Eppendorf tubes. Thousand microliters of DNA extraction buffer (100 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0); 50 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) (pH 8.0); 500 mM NaCl; 2% sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS; w/v); 2% 2-mercaptoethanol (v/v); 1% polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP; w/v)) were added and mixed well. The mixture was incubated at 65°C in a water bath for 40 min with intermittent shaking at 5-min intervals. It was centrifuged at 12,000 g for 15 min at 4°C, the supernatant was transferred into a new 1.5-ml tube and mixed with an equal volume of phenol:chloroform:isoamylalcohol (25:24:1) and centrifuged. The supernatant was collected and mixed with 1/10 volume 10% cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide–0.7 M NaCl in a new tube. After centrifugation (12,000 g for 15 min), the supernatant was collected and an equal volume of chloroform:isoamylalcohol (24:1) was added and mixed gently. The DNA was precipitated by the addition of 0.6 volume of cold isopropanol and left at −20°C for 10 min. The DNA was pelleted by centrifugation (12,000 g for 15 min) and the isopropanol was poured off; the DNA was allowed to air-dry before being dissolved in 100 μl of Tris-EDTA (TE) buffer.

sec.title: Random amplification of polymorphic DNA
sec.p: Samples were screened for RAPD variation using standard 20-base primers supplied by Operon (Alameda, CA, USA). Thirty microliters of reaction cocktail was prepared by mixing the following: 10× buffer 3.0 μl, deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates (10 mM) 1.2 μl, magnesium chloride (25 mM) 1.2 μl, primer (5 μM) 2.0 μl, Taq polymerase (5 unit) 0.4 μl, water 19.2 μl, sample DNA 3.0 μl (100 ng/μl). Totally 32 oligonucleotide primers were screened on C. arvensis and among them, 13 primers showed clear polymorphic patterns. The thermal cycler (Eppendorf Company, USA) was programmed as 2 min at 95°C; 2 cycles of 30 s at 95°C, 1 min at 37°C, 2 min at 72°C; 2 cycles of 30 s at 95°C, 1 min at 35°C, 2 min at 72°C; 41 cycles of 30 s at 94°C, 1 min at 35°C, 2 min at 72°C; followed by a final 5 min extension at 72°C then brought down to 4°C.

sec.title: Electrophoresis
sec.p: The PCR products (27 μl) were mixed with 6× gel loading buffer (3 μl) and loaded onto an agarose (1.5%, w/v) gel electrophoresis in 0.5× Tris-borate-EDTA (TBE) buffer at 70 V for 150 min. Amplification products separated by gel was stained in ethidium bromide (Etbr) solution (2 μl Etbr/100 ml 1× TBE buffer) for 40 min. The amplified DNA product was detected using the Bio Doc Image Analysis System with Uvisoft analysis package (Cambridge Electronic Design Ltd, Cambridge, UK). RAPD patterns were evaluated using the computer software TotalLab TL120 (Nonlinear Dynamics Ltd, UK).

sec.title: Determination of total protein content
sec.p:
Total proteins in the ground tissue of roots, shoot and leaves systems of Zea mays seedling were estimated according to Lowry et al. (1951). Each experiment was performed at least three times. Data were analyzed using a one-way ANOVA test using SPSS 12.0 for Microsoft Windows, and means were compared by Duncan’s multiple range tests at the 0.001 level of confidence. Increase rate (IR %) was calculated by the following formula:
IR=1−xy×100
where x and y are the average values detected in the control and each sample treated, respectively.

sec.title: SDS-PAGE electrophoresis
sec.p: Equal amount of protein, along with bromphenol blue and glycerol to final concentration of 12.5%, was added to 3–10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) gel as described in Laemmli (1970).

sec.title: Estimation of genomic template stability
sec.p:
Each change observed in RAPD profiles (disappearance of bands and appearance of new bands) was given the arbitrary score of +1, and the average was calculated for each experiment group of odd turnip seedlings with 13 primers which showed clear variations in RAPD profiles. The GTS (%) was calculated for each primer as follows:
GTS%=1−an×100
where a is the average number of changes in DNA profiles and n is the number of bands selected in control DNA profiles. Polymorphism in RAPD profiles included disappearance of a normal band and appearance of a new PCR band in comparison to control RAPD profiles (Atienzar et al., 1999; Liu et al., 2007) (Figure 1).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of the 32 decamer oligonucleotide primers tested, only 13 gave specific and stable results. The RAPD results showed that leaf, root and stem extract changed the number, size and intensity of amplified DNA fragments. Tables 1, 2 and 3 indicate that changed bands are observed in RAPD profiles for example appearance, disappearance of bands, increase and decrease in band intensity in comparison to RAPD profiles of the control. The decreased band intensity was particularly obvious for corn exposed to different concentrations of methanol extracts for primer OPA-2, OPA-6 and OPY-6. On the other hand, new RAPD bands appeared mainly for 50 μl and 75 μl concentrations of leaf, root and stem extracts especially for primers OPB-8, OPY-15, OPW-5 and OPH-14. Increased concentration of extracts caused decreasing GTS value and increasing polymorphism values. The polymorphism values and GTS were clearly dose dependent. GTS value of stem, leaf and root extracts in different concentrations (50, 75 and 100 μl) were 60.3, 44, 31.1, 62.3, 52.7, 45.7, 67.5, 47.7 and 44.1, respectively (Tables 4, 5 and 6). In all cases, polymorphisms were due to the loss and/or gain of the amplified bands in the treated samples in comparison to the control profiles (Tables 1, 2 and 3). Changes in the RAPD pattern were expressed as decrease in GTS. Especially, the 100 µl concentration of stem extracts increased the polymorphism value and decreased the GTS value (Table 1).

sec.p: Different concentration extracts of C. arvensis increased significantly the total protein when compared with the control (Table 7). Such an increase was found to be statistically significant (p < 0.05). IR % clearly demonstrates the dose-dependent response of C. arvensis on the levels of total proteins (Table 7). IR values of root, stem and leaf and in different concentrations of extracts were 2.34, 6.35, 13.82, 5.84, 13.82, 14.76, 9.96, 3.61 and 2.00, respectively. In addition, on PAGE the separated proteins showed bands ranging from 3 to 69 kDa. There was a little change in profiles but the accumulation of the proteins and the intensity of the bands have showed variability.

caption.p: Total soluble protein level in different concentrations of leaf, root and stem extracts on corn seed after 7-day exposure.a

fn.p: aThe mean difference is significant at the 0.05 level.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, protein analysis and RAPD analysis were adapted to examine the genotoxic effect of C. arvensis methanolic extract on corn seed. Relatively few studies have used molecular techniques to examine the genotoxic effect of plant allelochemicals (Sunar et al., 2009). RAPD-PCR-based assays are important as a genomewide DNA variation screening strategy. DNA damage, genetic instability and mutagenic effects have been evaluated with RAPD analysis (Atienzar and Jha, 2006; Uzonur et al., 2004). RAPD assay has been proved to be a useful tool to detect the genomic instability manifested such as point mutations, genetic and chromosomal rearrangements, deletion and insertions (Liu et al., 2007; Taspinar et al., 2011). Relatively few studies have used molecular techniques to examine the genotoxic effect of plant allelochemicals. Genotoxic effect of allelochemicals has been studied by several authors using different organisms and test techniques (Sunar et al., 2009; Turker et al., 2008). This is the first report on genotoxic effect of allelochemical C. arvensis extracts in corn. But, Kazinczi et al. (2007) reported that aqueous extracts of C. arvensis decreased the germination and seedling growth in crop plants, and this phytotoxic properties have been linked with compounds such as flavonoids, polyphenols and phenoloid compounds (chlorogenic acid and rutin).

Some recent studies have reported that volatile oil from several allelopathic plants and their monoterpenes caused accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (H2O2 and O2) in some plants (Batish et al., 2006; Mutlu et al., 2011; Oracz et al., 2007; Singh et al., 2006, 2009). Oxidative stress occurs when the production of ROS exceeds the plant’s natural antioxidant defense mechanisms, causing damage to macromolecules such as DNA, proteins and lipids. Changes in the RAPD pattern and decreases in GTS may be due to oxidative damage caused by the allelochemical. In addition, this study investigated the adverse effects of C. arvensis methanolic extract on corn seed using protein analysis. The results demonstrated that low concentrations of root, stem and leaf (50 µl) have not changed significantly when compared with control as seen in Table 7. However, other concentrations of leaf and root (75 and 100 μl) caused progressive increase in the levels of total protein. Such an increase was found to be statistically significant (p < 0.05). Results of protein electrophoresis showed that there was a change in the profiles of protein bands. Changes in protein band profiles may cause point mutations, genetic and chromosomal rearrangements, deletion, insertions and methylation in DNA. Also, increase in total protein levels can be suggested as one of the mechanisms for their genotoxic effects resulting in cell death. Additional studies are being conducted to test this hypothesis.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This study was supported by grants from the research funds appropriated to Atatürk University (Project no. 2009/238).
